summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney Maurene Comey and defense attorney Christian Everdell regarding redactions to Judge Nathan's opinion and order denying bail for Jeffrey Epstein. The parties agree no redactions are necessary and draft a joint letter to the court.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney communicating with the prosecution about redactions to a bail order; suggests drafting a joint letter to the court.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who agrees with the defense position and attaches a draft joint letter to the court.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Copied on the email correspondence regarding redactions to the bail order.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Copied on the email correspondence regarding redactions to the bail order.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on the email correspondence regarding redactions to the bail order.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Copied on the email correspondence regarding redactions to the bail order.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Issued the opinion and order denying bail that is the subject of the redaction discussion.

events.title: Email Correspondence on Bail Order Redactions
events.description: Prosecution and defense attorneys exchange emails agreeing that no redactions are necessary to Judge Nathan's opinion and order denying bail, and draft a joint letter to the court.

keyFacts: The document is an email chain from December 30, 2020, regarding procedural matters in the Jeffrey Epstein case.
Prosecution and defense attorneys agree that no redactions are necessary to Judge Nathan's opinion and order denying bail.
The parties are preparing a joint letter to the court as ordered by the judge.
The correspondence shows coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Epstein's defense team on administrative court matters.
